Sven Beckert at Harvard Book Store
ğŸ“… Tuesday, December 02, 2025
ğŸ• 07:00 PM
ğŸ“ Harvard Book Store, 1256 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ Free
arts and culture
Harvard Book Store welcomes Sven Beckertâ€”Laird Bell Professor of History at Harvard University and author of the acclaimed book Empire of Cottonâ€”for a discussion of his new book Capitalism: A Global History. He will be joined in conversation by Manisha Sinhaâ€”the Draper Chair in American History at the University of Connecticut and Past President of the Society for Historians of the Early American Republic. A landmark event years in the making, a brilliant global narrative that unravels the defining story of the past thousand years of human history No other phenomenon has shaped human history as decisively as capitalism. It structures how we live and work, how we think about ourselves and others, how we organize our politics. Sven Beckert, author of the Bancroft Prizeâ€“winning Empire of Cotton, places the story of capitalism within the largest conceivable geographical and historical framework, tracing its history during the past millennium and across the world. An epic achievement, his book takes us into merchant businesses in Aden and car factories in Turin, onto the terrifyingly violent sugar plantations in Barbados, and within the world of women workers in textile factories in todayâ€™s Cambodia. Capitalism, argues Beckert, was born global. Emerging from trading communities across Asia, Africa, and Europe, capitalismâ€™s radical recasting of economic life rooted itself only gradually. But then it burst onto the world scene, as a powerful alliance between European states and merchants propelled them, and their economic logic, across the oceans. This, Beckert shows, was modern capitalismâ€™s big bang, and one of its epicenters was the slave labor camps of the Caribbean. This system, with its hierarchies that haunt us still, provided the liftoff for the radical transformations of the Industrial Revolution. Fueled by vast productivity increases along with coal and oil, capitalism pulled down old ways of life to crown itself the defining force of the modern world. This epic d

Terence Keel at Harvard Book Store
ğŸ“… Wednesday, December 03, 2025
ğŸ• 07:00 PM
ğŸ“ Harvard Book Store, 1256 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ Free
arts and culture
Harvard Book Store welcomes Terence Keelâ€”award-winning scholar, the founding director of the BioCritical Studies Lab, and a professor of human biology, society, and African American studies at the University of California, Los Angelesâ€”for a discussion of his new book The Coroner's Silence: Death Records and the Hidden Victims of Police Violence. He will be joined in conversation by Zohra Ahmedâ€”an associate professor of law at Boston University. For readers of His Name Is George Floyd and Under the Skin. A landmark investigation into forensic medicine that exposes the systematic concealment of state-sanctioned violence through death investigations Each year, police officers kill over 1,000 people they've sworn to protect and serve. While some cases, like George Floyd's and Sandra Bland's, capture national attention, most victims remain nameless, their stories untold. The Coroner's Silence reveals a disturbing truth about these cases: coroners and other death investigators are often complicit in obscuring the violent circumstances of in-custody deaths. Through rigorous researchâ€”including critical records analysis, public health studies, and interviews with victims' familiesâ€”this book unmasks the systemic failures within forensic medicine. Terence Keel shows how incomplete autopsy reports, mishandled medical documents, and strategically lost evidence effectively shield law enforcement from accountability. The Coronerâ€™s Silence uncovers how the current system of death investigation operates as a mechanism of institutional safeguarding. By highlighting the structural powerlessness of coroners and their disconnection from the communities most affected by police violence, Keel demonstrates how bureaucratic processes can render human suffering invisible. True accountability requires more than procedural reform. It demands a fundamental reimagining of how we investigate, document, and understand deaths at the hands of state institutions. The Coroner's Silence is a crucial in

ğŸ“… Thursday, December 04, 2025
ğŸ• 07:00 PM
ğŸ“ Harvard Book Store, 1256 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ Free
arts and culture
Harvard Book Store welcomes Anthony M. Amoreâ€”Director of Security and Chief Investigator at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, and the bestselling author of Stealing Rembrandts, The Art of the Con, and The Woman Who Stole Vermeerâ€”for a discussion of his new book, The Rembrandt Heist: The Story of a Criminal Genius, a Stolen Masterpiece, and an Enigmatic Friendship. He will be joined in conversation by Kelly Horanâ€”The Boston Globeâ€™s deputy editor for the "Ideas" section in Globe Opinion and a member of the Globeâ€™s editorial board. A true crime tale of unbelievable friendship, loyalty, criminal genius, and a staggeringly audacious plot to steal one of the worldâ€™s most valuable paintingsâ€”and return it. On April 14, 1975, Myles Connor, already a known art thief, entered the Boston Museum of Fine Arts in disguise along with a cohort. The pair went directly the Dutch Gallery and proceeded to remove Portrait of Elsbeth van Rijn from its place on the wall. After a brief scuffle with the guardsâ€”with Myles deterring his partner from shooting a bystanderâ€”the pair was gone, leaving behind no traceable evidence amidst the mayhem.

ğŸ“… Friday, December 05, 2025
ğŸ• 04:00 PM
ğŸ“ Warehouse, 1256 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ Free
arts and culture
The Harvard Book Store Warehouse Sale features thousands of new books deeply discounted up to 40-80% off the list price. The sale features books across genres, hardcover and paperback, adult and children's literature. For fans of our used books department, a featured selection is available at the sale to browse as well. The Warehouse Sale also features other bookish merchandise including totes, stationary, and apparel. Are you a member of our free Frequent Buyer Program? If so, Friday, December 5 is just for you! Join us at our warehouse in Needham, between 4 PM and 7 PM for exclusive early access to the sale. On Saturday, December 6 and Sunday December 7, the warehouse sale will be open to all customers from 9am-7pm both days.

In celebration of the 250th anniversary of Jane Austen's birth, Harvard Book Store welcomes Janet Lewis Saidiâ€”creator of The Austen Connection, a public-humanities and journalism project that connects Austenâ€™s literature to the pop-culture and current events of our world todayâ€”and Alexandra Socaridesâ€”Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs at Emerson College, where she is a Professor of Writing, Literature, and Publishingâ€”for a discussion of Saidi's book Jane Austen: The Original Romance Novelist, a beautifully curated book that is both an inspiring biography and a celebration of literary brilliance. They will be joined in conversation by Deidre Lynchâ€”Ernest Bernbaum Professor of English Literature at Harvard University. Take a trip back in time to the Regency-era life of Jane Austen, one of literatureâ€™s most beloved novelists, with this captivating exploration of her works and the timeless themes of romance, family, and society. Pocket Portraits: Jane Austen takes you through the moments of Jane Austenâ€™s lifeâ€”some well-known and some which may be unexpected. These are the moments that shaped her six published novels, which draw deeply on themes of family, agency, philosophy, and love. From excerpts of her swoon-worthy tales like Pride and Prejudice and Emma to insight into Austenâ€™s social commentary and why her works still leave their mark on contemporary pop culture, this book paints a vivid portrait of the complicated woman behind the quill. This beautifully curated book is both an inspiring biography and a celebration of literary brilliance. Whether youâ€™re a longtime admirer of Austen or just beginning your literary adventure, Pocket Portraits: Jane Austen will leave you fascinated, inspired, and longing for more. Janet Lewis Saidi is the creator of The Austen Connection, a public-humanities and journalism project that connects Austenâ€™s literature to the pop-culture and current events of our world today. For fans of our used books department, a featured selection is available at the sale to browse as well. Our Needham location has ample parking. The best ways to get to Needham (from Cambridge) is to take the 71 to Watertown Square, transfer onto the 59 bus to Reservoir Street, followed by a short walk. Broadway Trivia
ğŸ“… Tuesday, November 25, 2025
ğŸ• 07:00 PM
ğŸ“ Lamplighter Brewing, 284 Broadway, Cambridge
food and drink
Attend one of our most beloved, longest standing brewery traditions: Trivia Tuesday! Every Tuesday swing by our Broadway taproom for our weekly trivia night. Itâ€™s free to compete, and winners get beer money. Hereâ€™s how it works: show up with your team of 2 â€“ 6 players starting at 7:00 pm, when weâ€™ll open the doors to the back taproom. Head down the hallway to the back, then snag a seat. All seating is first come first serve, so we recommend arriving early â€“ there generally is a line! The game will start at 7:30 pm, and is about two hours long (with plenty of beer breaks, of course). Questions rotate every week, and cover categories ranging from history, politics, sports, movies, pop culture, music, and more. At the end of the game, 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place teams will be awarded Lamplighter gift cards â€“ good for usage in either of our taprooms and at Pepita Coffee Co. In addition to Trivia Tuesday at our Broadway taproom, we also host weekly trivia at our CX taproom. That game takes place on Monday evenings, and is also free to join for teams of 2 â€“ 6. Weâ€™d love to see you at either or both! Hungry? Munch on our signature giant soft pretzels or some crunchy nachos, which are available Tuesday evenings only. Youâ€™re also always welcome to bring your own food or order in, ask our staff for their favorite local recommendations. See you at trivia night! You must be 21+ attend, all guests will be asked to show valid government ID. Questions? Get in touch! You can reach us at events@lamplighterbrewing.com

ğŸ“… Wednesday, November 26, 2025
ğŸ• 08:00 PM
ğŸ“ Lamplighter CX, 110 N First St, Cambridge
food and drink
Join us every Wednesday at Lamplighter CX for a Survivor Watch Party! Grab your friends and settle in for the most thrilling, strategic, and jaw-dropping moments of Survivor. Don't let the beers distract you from the competition - we'll also be playing survivor bingo, with the winners getting a chance to spin the prize wheel. The competition will be fierce on and off the screen. Doors open at 7 pm, with the screening starting at 8:00 pm. All seating is first come, first serve, so plan on arriving early if you have a larger group. Please note that this event is 21+ and all guests must show a valid government-issued ID upon entry to our taproom. All space and seating is first come first serve, and an RSVP here does not guarantee entry. Questions? Get in touch: events@lamplighterbrewing.com.
Pepita Lo-Fi Friday
ğŸ“… Friday, November 28, 2025
ğŸ• 08:00 AM
ğŸ“ Lamplighter Brewing, 284 Broadway, Cambridge
food and drink
Lo-Fi Fridays are here! Just like our Lo-Fi weekends but now during the work week! Stop by the â€œsecretâ€ back taproom of our sweet little cafe space every Friday morning for a quiet sanctuary of productivity and peace. Need a bit of quiet time? The Lamplighter + Pepita team are here to bring you a little slice of calm. From here on out, we will open the back taproom from 8am-2pm on Friday mornings for Lo Fi Fridays. Think of it as a designated calming, quiet zone just for our Pepita patrons. Weâ€™ll play chill, ambient music to set the vibe, and folks are encouraged to read, work, study, etc. with minimal talking preferred. Grab a coffee and cozy up in the back taproom at our 284 Broadway location to soak up that tranquil energy or to get a jump start on the week ahead. Your weekend brunch plans have never been more relaxing! P.S. If youâ€™re not feeling quiet time, the front taproom will remain open as usual for normal operations.

Think of it as a designated calming, quiet zone just for our Pepita patrons. Weâ€™ll play chill, ambient music to set the vibe, and folks are encouraged to read, work, study, etc. with minimal talking preferred. Grab a coffee and cozy up in the back taproom at our 284 Broadway location to soak up that tranquil energy or to get a jump start on the week ahead. Your weekend brunch plans have never been more relaxing! P.S. If youâ€™re not feeling quiet time, the front taproom will remain open as usual for normal operations.
Brewery Tour & Tasting
ğŸ“… Saturday, December 06, 2025
ğŸ• 04:00 PM
ğŸ“ Lamplighter Brewing, 284 Broadway, Cambridge
food and drink
Break out your notebook and freshly sharpened No. 2 pencils because weâ€™re going back to school! We're offering brewery tours at our original 284 Broadway location on the first Saturday of every month. Space is limited, so snag your spot right here by purchasing a ticket. Our knowledgeable team will lead you on an interactive, behind-the-scenes tour of the production floor at Lamp, where youâ€™ll learn the essentials of craft beer-making, and how it all works at our compact, Cambridge-based facility. You'll also taste your way through the brewing process, sampling three of our current favorite draft pour picks, plus a special bonus beer to start the sipping syllabus. Will you graduate top of your class? Either way, we think youâ€™ll find your new favorite subject. Each ticket includes: ğŸ»One 6 oz welcome beer, plus 3 - 5 oz flight glass-sized samples ğŸš¶ğŸ¼A 60 min guided tasting and behind-the-scenes brewery tour ğŸ“ Beer School "quiz" and informational answer key ğŸ“š A Lamplighter Beer School diploma :) Questions? Get in touch! events@lamplighterbrewing.com. Please note that this event is 21+ and all guests will be asked to show a valid government-issued ID. Refund Policy We understand that plans sometimes change. If you provide us with more than 24 hours' notice prior to the event start time, we will issue a full refund to your original payment method. Within 24 hours of the start time, we will offer a refund in the form of credit to be used for a future ticketed event hosted by Lamplighter, valid for 1 year. Please note that Eventbrite fees, including processing and service fees, are nonrefundable as they are charged by Eventbrite and not under the control of Lamplighter. Please request refunds through Eventbrite, on your order confirmation page.

ğŸ“… Tuesday, December 09, 2025
ğŸ• 06:00 PM
ğŸ“ Lamplighter CX, 110 N First St, Cambridge
food and drink
Grab a drink and join us for this inclusive, beginner-friendly pottery workshop at Lamplighter! Holiday Edition: Add a little handmade holiday magic to your season by sculpting functional festive decor or heartfelt gifts from clay. Make ornaments, candle holders, holiday trays, mini trees, or whatever you dream up. Think cozy, joyful, messily creative energy, because the best gifts are always the ones you make yourself. Youâ€™ll learn hand-building techniques and shape your own one-of-a-kind clay cup, perfect for coffee, tea, beer or whatever warms your soul. Bonus: it's just as satisfying to drink from as it is to make! Delicious drinks available for purchase! This workshop is 21+ only.
Broadway Trivia
ğŸ“… Tuesday, December 09, 2025
ğŸ• 07:00 PM
ğŸ“ Lamplighter Brewing, 284 Broadway, Cambridge
food and drink
Attend one of our most beloved, longest standing brewery traditions: Trivia Tuesday! Every Tuesday swing by our Broadway taproom for our weekly trivia night. Itâ€™s free to compete, and winners get beer money. Hereâ€™s how it works: show up with your team of 2 â€“ 6 players starting at 7:00 pm, when weâ€™ll open the doors to the back taproom. Head down the hallway to the back, then snag a seat. All seating is first come first serve, so we recommend arriving early â€“ there generally is a line! The game will start at 7:30 pm, and is about two hours long (with plenty of beer breaks, of course). Questions rotate every week, and cover categories ranging from history, politics, sports, movies, pop culture, music, and more. At the end of the game, 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place teams will be awarded Lamplighter gift cards â€“ good for usage in either of our taprooms and at Pepita Coffee Co. In addition to Trivia Tuesday at our Broadway taproom, we also host weekly trivia at our CX taproom. That game takes place on Monday evenings, and is also free to join for teams of 2 â€“ 6. Weâ€™d love to see you at either or both! Hungry? Munch on our signature giant soft pretzels or some crunchy nachos, which are available Tuesday evenings only. Youâ€™re also always welcome to bring your own food or order in, ask our staff for their favorite local recommendations. See you at trivia night! You must be 21+ attend, all guests will be asked to show valid government ID. Questions? Get in touch! You can reach us at events@lamplighterbrewing.com

Gingerbread House Competition
ğŸ“… Saturday, December 13, 2025
ğŸ• 03:00 PM
ğŸ“ Lamplighter CX, 110 N First St, Cambridge
food and drink
LEARN MORE AND SIGN UP HERE Join us for our first-ever Gingerbread House Building Competition. Participate as a contestant or come for free as a spectator to cheer on the builders and enjoy the drink specials. A portion of ticket sales will support our community partner, Project Bread. And there will be plenty of our collaboration beer, Bread Zeppelin, a Ginger-Spiced Ale to enjoy as well. Contestants will get a base kit of building supplies (but you're free to bring any supplemental materials needed to enhance your designs). The kit includes four walls, a roof, icing, and assorted candies. You'll have an hour to build your masterpiece before the judging begins. There will be a winner chosen by our esteemed panel of judges, and one audience favorite. Test your skills, get in the holiday spirit, and support a good cause!

Weâ€™ll lead you through a guided flow with a focus on stretching, breathing, and light activity â€“ you might work up a light sweat, but nothing too strenuous. The class takes place in our upstairs taproom at Lamplighter Brewing Co.â€™s CX location (110 N First St, Cambridge MA). Your ticket includes full access to the yoga class as well as a beer, cold brew coffee, or kombucha. Sushi Making Cooking Class
ğŸ“… Sunday, December 21, 2025
ğŸ• 04:00 PM
ğŸ“ Lamplighter CX, 110 N First St, Cambridge
food and drink
With over two decades of sushi-making expertise stretching from California to Boston, Chef Harold is ready to share his knowledge with you. This sushi fundamentals class is free of gluten, nuts and dairy, and focuses on medium inside-out rolls, or uramaki, and hand rolls, or temaki. Begin the hands-on class with miso soup, then move on to mastering sushi rolling. You'll start with a shrimp tempura hand roll, then craft a delicious sweet potato hand roll. To finish, you'll learn the secrets to making a spicy tuna roll.

ğŸ“ Porter Square Books - Cambridge, 1815 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge

This will be a blended genre club where we read pieces of nonfiction, fiction, and poetry to learn about Black, Indigenous, Latinx, and Asian American experiences. Example of books: There is a Rio Grande in Heaven by Ruben Reyes Jr., Making of Asian America by Erika Lee, and Felon by Reginald Dwayne Betts. Pixel Party
ğŸ“… Saturday, November 15, 2025
ğŸ• 04:00 PM
ğŸ“ Portico Brewing, 101 South St, Somerville
food and drink
Build a wooden model of an iconic Nintendo character! Each participant will be given a set of painted wooden blocks that correspond with their chosen character. You will then be guided step by step on how to glue the blocks together to make a wooden model of a character from the 8-bit era of gaming. All materials will be provided and no experience is necessary. Final sculptures will vary in size. The tallest is Samus (13 inches) and the shortest are Mario & Link (each 6.7 inches). If you do not finish your sculpture during the event, you are welcome to take everything you need to finish it at home. If you would like to build a character that is not listed in the dropdown menu, feel free to email robertpatricklynch@gmail.com with requests. This is an all ages event. Children under 13 should be signed up at their parent/guardian's discretion. They will need adult supervision and have the ability to sit and do a project for 1-2 hours without being disruptive.

Jazz Composers Alliance Orchestra-Mini
ğŸ“… Sunday, November 23, 2025
ğŸ• 04:45 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $15
music
$15 admission / $10 student + seniors / 4:45 doors / 5pm start / seated JCAâ€™s Orchestra-Mini is a 10 piece ensemble who premiered last March at the LilyPad returns. We have a new collection of original extended jazz compositions by JCA resident composers Darrell Katz, Bob Pilkington, David Harris, and Mimi Rabson. The JCA Orchestra-Mini is a new ensemble created out of the personnel of our full jazz orchestra. Composers are the regular JCA composers: Darrell Katz, Bob Pilkington, David Harris, and Mimi Rabson. We have the feel of chamber jazz but the energy of the full jazz orchestra. The writing style of the composers is fairly diverse and always interesting. The web site for the full organization is jazzcomposersalliance.org

Jerry Bergonzi Quartet
ğŸ“… Monday, November 24, 2025
ğŸ• 08:30 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $15
music
Jerry Bergonzi, Tenor Saxophone A fine, high-powered tenor saxophonist with a tone influenced by John Coltrane, a mastery of chord changes, and a strong musical imagination, Jerry Bergonzi has long had an underground following in the Boston area. He started on clarinet when he was eight, switching to alto at 12, and finally to tenor two years later. Bergonzi was inspired early on by Sonny Rollins, Coltrane, and Hank Mobley. He attended Lowell University and then after graduation played electric bass in local bands behind singers and strippers, saving up enough money to move to New York in 1972. After struggling in the Big Apple for seven years and gaining some recognition as a member of Two Generations of Brubeck and of the Dave Brubeck Quartet (with whom he appeared on several Concord albums during 1979-1981), Bergonzi moved back to Boston in 1981, where he developed a strong career both as a tenorman and as an educator. He has since led several groups (including two called Con Brio and Gonz) and recorded for the Plug, Not Fat, Red, and Blue Note labels. â€” By Scott Yanow, AllMusic
The Fringe
ğŸ“… Monday, November 24, 2025
ğŸ• 10:00 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $15
music
The Fringe originally formed back in 1971 by tenor-saxophonist George Garzone, bassist Richard Appleman, and drummer Bob Gullotti as an outlet for their free jazz improvisations, The Fringe have entertained and enlightened Boston area jazz audiences for over 50 years. Bassist Appleman left the band in 1985 to become Chairman of the Bass Department at Berklee College and was replaced by veteran bassist John Lockwood. Bob Gullotti passed away in 2020 and is remembered as one of the greatest jazz drummers of his generation. Francisco Mela, now on drums, graciously fills the space Bob left behind. Along with their impressive tenure with The Fringe, Garzone, Lockwood, and Mela are in great demand as session players and have played with many of the greats of contemporary jazz. Along with keeping up with a busy performance schedule, each of them are well-respected educators helping to inspire the jazz musicians of tomorrow. George Garzone, Tenor Saxophone Lineup subject to change without notice
Donal Logue - workshopping story telling

ğŸ• 07:30 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
music
Donal Logue - workshopping story telling - Live music at The Lily Pad in Inman Square, Cambridge
Gill Aharon Trio
ğŸ“… Wednesday, November 26, 2025
ğŸ• 08:15 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $10
music
Inspired by the cartoon music of the 50s and 60s, the drive of Led Zeppelin, the genius and humor of Frank Zappa, the perfection of Bach, the relentlessness of Ligeti, the courage of Medeski, Martin and Wood, the jam of Phish live, the beauty of the Beatles and the immersive nature of music, I am in pursuit of truth through music. â€œSometimes I think of us musicians as kids playing in order to learn how to be adults, but we can just keep playing. The game of playing music together is too much fun to make it work. With that in mind, I refuse to write arrangements. I never want my friends and bandmates to feel obliged to do anything. - Gill Aharon

Louis ThÃ©lot Fusion 5tet
ğŸ“… Sunday, November 30, 2025
ğŸ• 09:30 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $15
music
$15 @ the door / $10 students / 9:30 doors / 10pm show This fusion project is a quintet led by French jazz violinist Louis ThÃ©lot, performing his original music, with Paul Vanier (keys), Aki Oliviero (guitar), Ferran Rico (bass) and Ben Fig (drums). The music is a fusion that draws on a wide range of multicultural influences. Louis ThÃ©lot is a French violinist, composer and arranger who grew up in the city of Lyon (France). He entered the National Conservatory of Lyon (CNSMD) in 2019, where he studied classical music with the world-class violinist Marc Danel (first violin of the Danel Quartet). In the meantime, he studied jazz and other music with RÃ©mi Crambes, an outstanding contemporary jazz violinist and composer. He performed in France and other European countries in many different places, such as the 'OpÃ©ra de Lyon', the 'Philharmonie de Paris', or the 'Jazz Ã  Vienne' or Lake Garda festivals, playing in symphonic orchestras, chamber orchestras, as a soloist, as well as a jazz/rock band leader and composer. In 2022 he obtained a scholarship to enter the Berklee College of Music, where he studied jazz performance and composition until his graduation in Spring 2025.

Berklee Strings Takeover with Honeyjaw and the Berklee Contemporary Cello Ensemble
ğŸ“… Tuesday, December 02, 2025
ğŸ• 07:30 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $10
music
$10-20 suggested donation / 7:30 doors / 8pm start / seated The Berklee Strings Takeover features two genre-defying student ensembles from the strings department playing an extremely wide range of styles and genres including metal, math rock, folk/roots, classical, alt rock, funk and jazz, all on traditional acoustic string instruments- come check it out! Featuring performances by Honeyjaw and the Berklee Contemporary Cello Ensemble. Honeyjaw is a group of Berklee students interpreting math rock and metal through the lens of roots instrumentation. They will be featuring songs by the Violinist, Kemedy Hauser, Megadeth, Black Sabbath, Chon, and Tool. Led by Strings Department faculty member and cellist Jeremy Harman, the Berklee Contemporary Cello Ensemble defies genres and convention, performing an eclectic mix of music including compositions and songs by Villa-Lobos, A Perfect Circle, Soundgarden, Vulfpeck, Weezer and original arrangements by members of the ensemble.
Jam Session with Nick Brust and Liz Sinn
ğŸ“… Tuesday, December 02, 2025
ğŸ• 10:00 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $15 / $10
music
$15 / $10 students / 10pm doors / 10:30 -12:30 show / seated Nick and Liz have put together a dynamic quartet comprised of some of Boston's finest to perform some uncommon standards and fiery original repertoire. The house band will play a set up front followed by an open jam session. Wielding a unique, incisive but soulful voice as an improviser and composer, Boston-based jazz saxophonist Nicholas Brust (pronounced â€œBruhstâ€) has established his voice in the world of modern improvised music. He has found his niche as a bandleader and sideman, taking advantage of the numerous textures and combinations available in the traditional jazz small-group format. Brust has performed and/or recorded with numerous highly acclaimed musicians, including Lage Lund, Gilad Hekselman (with bassist Jon Latona), Mark Ferber (with pianist Francesca Prihasti), The Peter Silver Big Band (sharing the stage with Roy Hargrove, Jimmy Owens, Steve Wilson and others), guitarist Ben Eunson, Kristina Koller (appearing in her Quintet at the 2020 NYC Winter Jazz Fest), and many others. Nicholas is currently on faculty at New England Conservatory as part of its Prep/Continuing Education division in addition to being an Artslink Teaching Artist for Berklee College of Musicâ€™s City Music program. Pianist and composer Liz Sinn has become an in-demand collaborator in New Englandâ€™s vibrant music scene, her journey rooted at Berklee College of Music. Though specializing in jazz, Liz brings versatility across genres, including various Latin American music styles, classical, musical theater, and pop. While in Boston, Liz has had the opportunity to perform with many notable musicians, including GRAMMY Award winners Neal Smith and Charlie Rosenâ€™s 8-Bit Big Band, as well as internationally recognized artists Il Divo, ChloÃ« Agnew of Celtic Woman, and Rafael Barata. Her skills as an arranger and copyist have also led to collaborations with renowned Latin American artists AndrÃ©s Cepeda and DaymÃ© Arocena, showcasin

Bert Seager's Heart of Hearing
ğŸ“… Wednesday, December 03, 2025
ğŸ• 07:00 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $15
music
Bert Seagerâ€™s Heart of Hearing is a-jazz quartet made up of piano, tenor-saxophone, upright-bass, and drums whose aim is to bring listeners into the heart of improvised jazz. The joyful expression of this musical intimacy, the shimmering transparency of the sound, and the sense that these musicians are as much involved in listening as in playing makes for compelling and memorable performances.

ğŸ’µ $25
music
The Adam Hersh Trio presents original jazz fusion. Influenced by some of the most innovative minds in the genreâ€”Chick Corea, Billy Childs, & Wayne Shorterâ€”the group uplifts new creative voices with Adam Hersh on piano & Max Gerl on bass, accompanied by Corea & Holdsworth's alum Gary Novak on drums. LA based pianist, keyboardist, & composer Adam Hersh was born in Castaic, CA. Since graduating from CSUN, Adam has been active in the LA jazz scene, performing & recording with musicians like Bob Sheppard, Mike Moreno, Warren Wolf, Munir Hossn, Bill Holman, Gary Novak, Billy Childs, Andrew Renfroe, Joe LaBarbera, & Gene Coye. Adam is a versatile musician, adept at learning & playing modern, fusion, & straight ahead originals & standards.

free collective disco
ğŸ“… Saturday, December 06, 2025
ğŸ• 04:30 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
food and drink
free admission / 4:30 start / all ages & family friendly Disco as meditation, experimental community joy and expression Drop by to dance, improvise, celebrate, seek! Enjoy a 2-hour playlist of participatory possibilities, centered around work by Dinosaur L / Arthur Russell. A library of toy percussion will be available to borrow and play during the event. We also welcome any pocket-sized sound makers you might like to bring from home. Bring your compassion & mutualism & curiosity, join as you are or as you dream to be. Host McMillan Ilderton is a social worker and performer who was born in the mid-1980s and has lived in Eastern MA since 2010. They enjoy creating community connections and creative possibilities!
Live at the Druid Presents "Will Woodson & Caitlin Finley"
ğŸ“… Saturday, December 06, 2025
ğŸ• 07:00 PM
ğŸ“ The Lily Pad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge
ğŸ’µ $20
music
$20 at door / $15 advance / 7pm doors / seated & standing Live Music from Will Woodson (Uileann Pipes & Flute) & Caitlin Finley (Fiddle) presented by Lilypadâ€™s friend and neighbor, The Druid Pub. The Druid Pub in Inman Square, renowned for its authentic Irish atmosphere and live traditional music, is launching a new concert series spotlighting global roots music. The concert series will take place next door at The Lilypad, a cozy venue in Inman Square, offering an intimate setting for this special event. Will Woodson (flute, uilleann pipes) and Caitlin Finley (fiddle) play sparky and driving traditional Irish music thatâ€™s grounded in the textures and rhythms of the rich Irish-American soundscape of the 1920s and 30s. With roots in the living Irish musical cultures of Boston, New York City, and Philadelphia, and a tremendous admiration for the first generation of recorded Irish musicians, the duo conjures up the sounds of the dance halls, vaudeville theaters, and house sessions central to Irish-American music from the first half of the twentieth century. In 2019, the two recorded their debut album, â€œThe Glory Reelâ€ alongside box player and piano accompanist Chris â€œJuniorâ€ Stevens, which Dan Neely of the Irish Echo called â€œa fabulous album from three of Irish Americaâ€™s finest.â€ During the pandemic years, the two made â€œThe Phonograph Projectâ€, a Patreon-supported series examining 78 recordings of traditional Irish music made in New York City in the 1920s and 30s. More recently, theyâ€™ve made musical appearances at the St. Louis TionÃ³l, the Patrick J. Touhey Memorial Weekend in Boston and the Ward Archives â€œArchiving Irish Americaâ€ conference in Milwaukee. Cait and Will live in Portland, Maine.
